chapters.name: Ottoman Officer (1881-1918)
topics: Who was the young Mustafa Kemal — born in Ottoman Salonica (modern Thessaloniki), the son of a minor customs official, educated at military academies where he excelled — and how did the declining Ottoman Empire shape a generation of young officers determined to modernize or die?

How did Kemal's early military career — fighting in Libya against the Italians (1911), the Balkan Wars (1912-1913), and internal Ottoman power struggles — hone both his military skills and his contempt for the sultanate's incompetence?

What was Kemal's role at Gallipoli (1915) — commanding the defense of the Chunuk Bair heights, famously telling his troops 'I don't order you to attack, I order you to die' — and how did this victory against the British and ANZAC forces make him a national hero?

How did World War I destroy the Ottoman Empire — catastrophic defeats, the Armenian Genocide (1915-1923), the British capture of Mesopotamia and Palestine, and the armistice that left Anatolia itself subject to partition — while Kemal watched from the Eastern Front?

What was the Treaty of Sèvres (1920) — which proposed to carve up Anatolia among Greece, France, Italy, Armenia, and Kurdistan, leaving Turkey a rump state — and why did this 'death sentence' galvanize Turkish resistance under Kemal's leadership?

chapters.name: The War of Independence (1919-1923)
topics: How did Kemal organize the Turkish War of Independence — defying the Ottoman sultan, establishing a rival government in Ankara, rallying former Ottoman officers and Anatolian irregulars — to resist the Allied partition of Turkey?

What was the Greco-Turkish War (1919-1922) — Greek forces advancing deep into Anatolia, Kemal's counteroffensive at the Battle of Sakyárya (1921) and the Battle of Dumlupınar (1922), and the recapture of Smyrna (modern Izmir) — and how did this victory secure Turkish sovereignty?

What was the Great Fire of Smyrna (September 1922) — the destruction of the Greek and Armenian quarters as Turkish forces retook the city, with estimates of 10,000-100,000 killed — and how does this event remain bitterly contested between Turkish and Greek national narratives?

How did the Treaty of Lausanne (1923) — replacing Sèvres, recognizing Turkish sovereignty over Anatolia and Eastern Thrace — represent Kemal's greatest diplomatic achievement and the only successful renegotiation of a post-World War I treaty?

What was the population exchange of 1923 — 1.5 million Greeks expelled from Turkey and 500,000 Turks expelled from Greece — and how did this forced migration, endorsed by the international community, establish a precedent for ethnic cleansing as state policy?

chapters.name: Building the Republic: The Kemalist Revolution (1923-1934)
topics: How did Atatürk proclaim the Turkish Republic on October 29, 1923 — abolishing the sultanate, establishing Ankara as the capital, and declaring that sovereignty belonged to the nation rather than a dynasty — in the most radical political transformation of the post-war period?

What was the abolition of the caliphate (March 1924) — ending 13 centuries of Islamic institutional authority, expelling the caliph, and declaring Turkey a secular state — and why did this decision shock the Muslim world while establishing the principle of Turkish secularism (laiklik)?

How did Atatürk's legal reforms transform Turkish society — replacing Islamic sharia law with the Swiss civil code, the Italian penal code, and the German commercial code — effectively importing an entire Western legal framework in a single generation?

What was the Hat Law of 1925 — banning the fez and requiring Western-style hats, enforced with arrests and even executions — and why did Atatürk consider dress reform essential, saying 'the civilized international dress is worthy and appropriate for our nation'?

How did Atatürk's alphabet revolution of 1928 — replacing the Arabic script with a Latin alphabet in just three months — simultaneously modernize communication, cut Turkey off from its Ottoman literary heritage, and make the population functionally illiterate overnight?

chapters.name: Women's Rights, Education, and Secularism
topics: How did Atatürk advance women's rights in Turkey — banning polygamy, granting equal inheritance rights, opening education and professions to women, and giving women the right to vote (1930 in municipal, 1934 in national elections) — before many European countries?

What role did education play in the Kemalist project — making primary education compulsory and co-educational, opening hundreds of schools, sending students abroad, and requiring the teaching of science rather than religion — in transforming an overwhelmingly rural, illiterate population?

How did Atatürk define Turkish secularism (laiklik) — not the French model of keeping religion out of public life, but state control OF religion through the Directorate of Religious Affairs — and why has this model generated ongoing tension between secular and religious Turks?

What were Atatürk's 'Six Arrows' — republicanism, populism, nationalism, secularism, statism, and reformism — and how did these principles, embedded in the constitution and enforced by the military, define Turkish political life for nearly a century?

How did Atatürk handle opposition — suppressing Kurdish revolts (Sheikh Said rebellion, 1925; Dersim massacre, 1937-1938), banning opposition parties, controlling the press, and executing opponents — while presenting himself as a democratic reformer?

chapters.name: Legacy: Father of the Turks
topics: How did Atatürk die on November 10, 1938 — of cirrhosis at age 57, his liver destroyed by decades of heavy drinking — and why does Turkey still observe a moment of silence at 9:05 AM every November 10, the exact time of his death?

Why was Atatürk given the surname meaning 'Father of the Turks' (1934) — a name that no other Turk may legally use — and how has his cult of personality, enforced by law (it is a crime to insult his memory), shaped Turkish political culture?

How has Erdoğan's Turkey challenged the Kemalist legacy — rolling back secularism, empowering political Islam, and rewriting the relationship between state and religion that Atatürk established — while still invoking Atatürk's name?

What is Atatürk's global legacy — the model of a military-led secular modernization that inspired leaders from Nasser to the Shah to Nehru — and why has this model largely failed elsewhere while Turkey's own version is under threat?

How does Atatürk's treatment of minorities — the Armenian Genocide denial, the Kurdish suppression, the Greek population exchange — complicate the narrative of the progressive nation-builder, and can his achievements be separated from these crimes?
